description: Easy - The Twelve Tables and Written Law

questions.question: What was the fundamental problem with Roman law before the Twelve Tables were created?
options: There were far too many written laws for average citizens to remember them
Laws existed only as unwritten customs that patrician magistrates could arbitrarily reinterpret
Laws were written in Greek instead of Latin, making them incomprehensible to citizens
Laws were changed by magistrates every single time a new consul took office
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Push for Written Law

questions.question: In what year were the Twelve Tables inscribed and displayed in the Forum?
options: 509 BCE when the Republic was first established
494 BCE when the first tribunes were created
450 BCE when the decemvirs completed their written legal code
400 BCE during the later stages of the early Republic
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Decemvirs and the Creation

questions.question: What does 'Lex Duodecim Tabularum' literally mean in Latin?
options: The law of twelve magistrates who governed together
The law of twelve tribes voting on major decisions
The law of the twelve bronze tablets inscribed with legal code
The law of twelve gods who protected the Roman state
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Decemvirs and the Creation

questions.question: Who were the decemvirs appointed to create Rome's written laws?
options: A group of ten senators chosen by the Senate for this task
A special commission of ten men given authority to draft legal code
Ten military generals who had won victories against Rome's enemies
Ten representatives elected directly by the plebeian assembly
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Decemvirs and the Creation

questions.question: Which legal code did the decemvirs reportedly study before drafting the Twelve Tables?
options: The laws of Egypt which had been written down centuries earlier
The Etruscan legal system used in the northern cities
The Carthaginian laws used by trading cities in North Africa
Greek law, particularly the legal code established in Athens
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Decemvirs and the Creation

questions.question: Why was the creation of written law a significant plebeian victory?
options: Laws were now public and could not be arbitrarily reinterpreted by patricians
It immediately eliminated the Senate and all patrician political power
It allowed plebeians to become consuls and hold the highest offices
It abolished debt slavery and freed all debtors enslaved to creditors

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT directly addressed by the Twelve Tables?
options: Rules governing property law, inheritance, and property disputes
Laws establishing family structure, marriage, and parental authority
Procedures for bringing lawsuits and conducting court trials
Formal requirements for plebeians to become senators and consuls
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Limitations - What the Twelve Tables Did NOT Solve

questions.question: Which aspect of the Twelve Tables actually reinforced existing patrician power?
options: Rules about property inheritance that gave equal shares to all heirs
Regulations regarding debt slavery and creditor power over debtors
Procedures restricting military commanders from leading armies alone
Requirements that all magistrates had to consult with tribunes
questions.text_reference: Section 5: What the Twelve Tables Contained

questions.question: How do modern historians know what content the Twelve Tables actually contained?
options: Ancient authors quoted and summarized the laws in their historical writings
The original bronze tablets survive intact in Roman museums today
Archaeological excavations uncovered clay tablets with complete word-for-word text
Livy provided a detailed word-for-word transcription in his historical work

questions.question: What was the most important long-term impact of making law written and public?
options: It eliminated all patrician privileges and made all citizens completely equal
It gave all plebeians immediate access to every magistracy and priesthood
It abolished slavery throughout the Roman state and freed all enslaved people
It established that law was objective and applied equally to all citizens
